title: Schedule
text: Please note that this schedule is filterable and searchable.

title: MATH 244: Intermediate Data Science
text:
Welcome! This website contains course information for MATH 244: Intermediate Data Science at Vassar College for the spring 2026 semester.





Artwork by @allison_horst

title: Notes
text:
All slides and handouts for this course can be accessed in Google Drive. Please note that you must have a Vassar email in order to access the folder.
01/23/25. 0-welcome. These slides give an overview of the course and the software we will be using.
01/28/25. 1-R-vs-Python. These slides compare and contrast R and Python and includes a few coding exercises.
01/30/25. Lab 1: Introduction to Git for Version Control.
02/04/25. 3-R-Python-datasci. These slides compare and contrast R and Python for manipulating datasets and includes a few coding exercises.
02/06/25. Lab 2: R, Python, and Git, Oh My!
02/11/25. 5-datavis-R. These slides discuss how you can create data visualizations in R. We also started Lab 3: Data Visualization in R and Python.
02/13/25. 6-datavis-py. These slides discuss how you can create data visualizations in Python. We also continued working on Lab 3: Data Visualization in R and Python.
02/18/25. 7-webscraping-R. These slides discuss how to web scrape in R and how to write functions in R. We also started working on Lab 4: Web Scraping in R.
02/20/25. 8-webscraping-R-py. These slides discuss how to web scrape in both R and Python at a larger scale. We continued working on Lab 4: Web Scraping in R.
02/25/25. 9-intro-machine-learning. These slides introduce machine learning by discussing supervised & unsupervised learning, regression, and classification.
02/27/25. 10-eval-models. These slides discuss how one can evaluate a model by thinking about mean square error, bias, and variance.
03/04/25. 11-datasci-ethics. These slides discuss data ethics and things to consider when pursuing your own data science projects.
03/06/25. Project work day.
03/25/25. 13-lin-reg. These slides discuss linear regression and how to implement it in Python.
03/27/25. 14-lasso-ridge and 13-lasso-ridge-code. These slides discuss ridge and lasso regression and how to implement these methods in Python and R.
04/01/25. 15-logistic. These slides discuss logistic regression and how to implement it in Python.
04/03/25. 16-svm. These slides discuss support vector machines and how to implement them in Python.
04/08/25. 17-trees. These slides discuss decision tree modeling and implementing them in Python.
04/10/25. 18-forests. These slides discuss bagging, boosting, and random forests and how to implement them in Python.
04/15/25. 19-unsupervised-PCA. These slides introduce unsupervised learning and give a brief overview of principal component analysis (PCA). I also talked about how I use unsupervised learning in my research.
04/17/25. 20-clustering. These slides and activities discuss k-means and hierarchical clustering.

title: Assignments
text: All homework, essays, labs, and project files can be accessed through the Google Drive. Please note that you must have a Vassar email in order to access the folder.

title: Assignments
section: Ungraded Assignments to Prepare for Class
text:
Ungraded Assignments to Prepare for Class
01/23/25. Install Python, R, and RStudio on your personal computer. See the syllabus for links to installation instructions. Additionally, look over the R vs. Python slides (in the folder Notes > 1-R-vs-Python) before class on Tuesday.
01/28/25. Install Git and make a Github account. See the syllabus for instructions.
01/30/25. Look over the slides in Notes > 3-R-Python-datasci before class on Tuesday. Additionally, fill out the course check-in by Monday. The form link is posted in Slack in #m244-announcements
02/06/25. Look over the slides in Notes > 5-datavis-R before class on Tuesday. Additionally, fill out the course check-in by Monday.
02/11/25. Look over the slides in Notes > 6-datavis-py before class on Thursday.
02/13/25. Look over the slides in Notes > 7-webscraping-R before class on Tuesday. Additionally, fill out the course check-in by Monday.
02/20/25. Fill out the course check-in by Monday.
02/27/25. Fill out the course check-in by Monday.
03/27/25. Fill out the course check-in which is a mid semester feedback survey by Monday. Additionally, look over the slides in Notes > 15-logistic before class on Tuesday.
04/15/25. Fill out the course check-in by Friday.

title: Assignments
text:
Homework
All homework assignments will be submitted to Gradescope.

Course Information sheet. This is due Thursday, January 30th.
Data Science in R and Python. This is due Thursday, February 13th.
Web Scraping in R. This is due Thursday, February 27th.
Regularization and Deforestation in Python. This is due Thursday, April 10th.
Unsupervised Learning. This is due Thursday, May 1st.

title: Assignments
text:
Essays

My Coding Autobiography. This is open ended and some things you can include are:
* When did you start coding and why?
* How do you learn coding?
* What have been your biggest successes and struggles with coding?
* What are your coding goals?
This is due Tuesday, February 4th in Gradescope.
Data Visualization. Read the two articles on misleading data visualizations during COVID-19 in the Essays > 2-data-vis folder. In your essay, include the following:
* Summarize the main take-aways in the two articles.
* Comment on both good or bad data visualizations you have encountered.
* What will be your general approach for approaching data visualizations in the future?
Your essay should be around 1-2 pages in length. This is due Thursday, February 20th in Gradescope.
Data Ethics. Read Data Science as Political Action: Grounding Data Science in a Politics of Justice in Essays > 3-ethics. In your essay include the following:
* Summarize the key points in Green’s article.
* In the context of your own personal values and Green’s article on the politics of data science, what do you think is important when it comes to the topics you and your group members picked for the project?
Your essay should be around 1-2 pages in length. This is due Thursday, March 27th in Gradescope.
There will be a final take-home essay during finals week.

title: Assignments
text:
Labs

Introduction to Git for Version Control. 01/30. We will finish it in class on Tuesday, February 4th.
R, Python, and Git: Oh My! 02/06. This is due Monday, February 10th in Gradescope.
Data Visualization in R and Python. 02/11 and 02/13. This is due Monday, February 17th in Gradescope.
Web Scraping in R. 02/18 and 02/20. This is due Monday, February 24th in Gradescope.
Linear Regression with Penguins. 02/25 and 02/27. This is due Monday, March 3rd in Gradescope.
Linear Regression in Python. 03/25 and 03/27. This lab consists of the in class exercises from these days. You can find them in the slides. This is due Monday, March 31st in Gradescope.
Logistic Regression and Support Vector Machines. 04/1 and 04/3. This lab consists of the in class exercises from these days. you can find them in the slides. This is due Monday, April 7th in Gradescope.
Trees for Evaluating Evaluations. 04/10. This lab was not collected.

Note there was no lab for the week of 3/3-3/6 (week before spring break).

title: Assignments
text:
Project

Project Proposal. This is due Wednesday, March 5th.
Exploratory Data Analysis. This is due Thursday, April 3rd.
Preliminary Analysis. This is due Thursday, April 17th.
Peer Review. This is due Thursday, April 24th.
Project Presentations. These will occur Thursday, May 1st and Tuesday, May 6th.
Final Report. This is due Tuesday, May 13th.

title: Events
text:
Monday, January 27. Dr. Daryl DeFord from Washington State University will give a talk titled Political Geometries: Analyzing Fairness in Redistricting with Statistics from 5-6 in Rocky 312. Tea time will be from 4:30-5 in Rocky 305.
Friday, January 31. Austin MBaye (VC ’24) from Northeastern University will give a talk titled Quantifying Repetitive Motor Patterns in Autism with Sliding Windows and n-Persistent Scoring (SWnPers) at our Math Colloquium. The talk is from 4-5 PM in Rocky 312. Tea time will be from 3:30-4 in Rocky 305.
Thursday, February 6. Dr. Shazeda Ahmed from UCLA will give a talk titled The Work of ‘Aligning’ Artificial Intelligence from 4-5:15 in Taylor 206 at the Data Science and Society Colloquium.
February 12-13. The Henry Seely White lectures this year will be given by Professor Xiao-Li Meng.
Wednesday, February 12. Learning, Teaching, and Communication in the Age of AI: Wisdom and Warnings from Harvard Data Science Review (Or: Are you smarter than GPT-4?) from 4-5 in Rocky 300.
Thursday, February 13. From a Cauchy Surprise to the Half-Cauchy Miracle from 2-3 in Rocky 300.
Additionally, students can meet with Dr. Xiao-Li Meng for lunch at noon on Thursday 2/13. Please reach out to me if you are interested.
Friday, February 21. Dr. Jamie Juul from Colorado State University will give a talk at our Math Colloquium. The talk is from 4-5 PM in Rocky 312. Tea time will be from 3:30-4 in Rocky 305.
Tuesday, February 25. Dr. Andrew Schultz from Wellesley College will give a talk titled The Math Behind Deomcratic Systems at our math colloquium. The talk is from 4-5 in Rocky 310. Tea time will be from 3:30-4 in Rocky 305.
Thursday, February 27. Dr. Nicole Holliday from UC Berkeley will present her latest research on how tone-detection systems and digital voice assistants like Siri and Alexa reinforce linguistic and racial bias. This talk will be from 7-9 PM in Rocky 300.
Tuesday, March 4. Dr. Elise Zheng from Columbia University will give a talk titled Sociotechnical Ethics of Big Data: Exploring the Intersection of Data, Knowledge, and Epistemic Justice at the DSS colloquium. This talk will be from 2-3 PM in Rocky 307.
Thursday, April 3. Katie Ellman-Aspnes from Notre Dame will give a talk titled Classification Theory and the Map of the Universe at the Math Colloquium. This talk will be from 4-5 in Rocky 305.
Saturday, April 5. The 31st Hudson River Undergraduate Mathematics Conference at Union College in Schenectady, New York. I hope you consider attending! Please let me know if you are interested in going.
April 11-13. DataFest is a data analysis competition where teams of up to five students have a weekend to attack a large, complex, and surprise dataset. Work together with your team members and consult with mentors to find and communicate insights into these data. The teams that impress the judges the most will win prizes. Everyone else will have a great experience, learn some new skills, and have fun! Go to the website to register.
Wednesday, April 23. Dr. Becca Thomases from Smith College will give a talk titled A Period-Doubling Route to Chaos in Viscoelastic Fluids. This talk will be from 4-5 in Rocky 300. Tea time will be at 3:30-4 in Rocky 305.

title: Syllabus
text:
Texts
We will use the following textbook:

Introduction to Statistical Learning: with Applications in Python by James, Witten, Hastie, Tibshirani, and Taylor (ISLP in Schedule). We will use this book for learning about core topics in machine learning.

Please note that there is a version of this book called Introduction to Statistical Learning: with Applications in R, which is the same book conceptually but with labs in R instead of Python. As we will be using Python for the machine learning components, I suggest that you download the Python version.
Please note that the pdf version of this textbook is free! There is no need to purchase a hard copy unless you want to.
For other topics, there will be readings posted to Moodle/Google Drive and linked in the schedule.

title: Syllabus
text:
Software
There are software requirements for the course. I highly recommend installing RStudio, R, Python, and Git to your personal computer. This is a very useful skill. However, I do not want this to be an obstacle for learning class material. Accessing these softwares through a server and web browser is also acceptable. See below for more details on each one.

R
We will use R and RStudio throughout this course. You may access both of these resources on the Vassar College server:

For on campus: http://rstudio.vassar.edu/
For off campus: https://libproxy.vassar.edu/login?url=https://rstudio.vassar.edu.

Alternatively (and recommended), you can download and install R on your computer at http://cran.r-project.org/, as well as RStudio which is available at https://posit.co/download/rstudio-desktop/. Please follow the instructions for downloading both here: https://moderndive.netlify.app/1-getting-started.html#installing (although note that since RStudio has become Posit, the steps for installing RStudio may be slightly different).

Reading More About R
If you want to brush up on your R skills, R for Data Science (2e) by Hadley Wickham, Mine Çetinkaya-Rundel, and Garrett Grolemund is an excellent introduction to the tidyverse approach to R programming.
If you are interested in R as a programming language, feel free to check out Hadley Wickham’s1 excellent Advanced R. You can access its contents for free online here: https://adv-r.hadley.nz/.



Python
We will be using Python for the machine learning components of the course. You should also install Python and Jupyter Notebook on your computer. There are many ways to do this. One way is to install the Anaconda distribution of Python; it collects a wide array of useful packages, libraries, and applications that make it possible to use Python on your own computer. You can install from https://www.anaconda.com/products/distribution. See https://docs.anaconda.com/anaconda/install/index.html for helpful instructions for different platforms.

Reading More About Python
There are many books written about Python. A good place to start is this link, which collects a list of 5 free books on learning Python.
In particular, Python for Everybody by Charles R. Severance is a great resource for those learning to use Python for data science, and A Whirlwind Tour of Python by Jake VanderPlas is a great introduction to Python in general; it serves as a necessary prerequisite to his Python Data Science Handbook.



Git
You also need to install Git. Please follow the instructions at this link to do so: http://rafalab.dfci.harvard.edu/dsbook/accessing-the-terminal-and-installing-git.html. A helpful resource for using Git is the ProGit online book.
You will also need to make a Github account, if you have not done so. Please see here for instructions: https://docs.github.com/en/get-started/signing-up-for-github/signing-up-for-a-new-github-account.
We will set-up Git together during the first lab so there is no need to do it before then.

title: Syllabus
text:
Course Communication
All course materials—including slides, worksheets, assignments, and other course resources—will be posted on the class Moodle. The Moodle page will either direct you to this course website or to the Google drive that contains the raw files you might want to download. Course communication will otherwise occur via our M 244 Slack workspace. In particular, I ask that you please not email me with course-related questions, but rather post these questions in the appropriate Slack channel. If discretion is needed, please feel free to direct message me on Slack.
During the week, I will try my best to answer all Slack messages within 24 hours of receiving them. However, if you message me over the weekend or holidays, I may not respond to your message until classes resume in an effort to maintain my own work-life balance. Please plan accordingly.

title: Syllabus
text:
Assignments and Evaluation

Participation (15%)
Please come to class ready to discuss and engage with the course material! A great way to do this is to complete the reading we will cover in class beforehand.
Attending class and arriving on time is required. You are allowed two unexcused absences and/or tardies. Each additional absence or tardiness will reduce your engagement grade by 5%. If you are unable to attend class (or need to arrive late) due to a family emergency, illness, religious holiday, etc., then please let me know as soon as possible so I can mark it as an excused absence. You do not need to tell me details of the situation, I will trust your word.
Limited screen policy. Engaging with unrelated content on a laptop, tablet, and/or phone during class time is a distraction for both you and others. I ask that you only use your technological devices to enhance your learning (e.g., writing notes on a tablet) or when they are needed during~class.


Labs (Part of Participation Grade)
A large portion of class time will be devoted to working through labs and tutorials. You will often work on a lab with your partner/group. You are expected to be fully enaged with the lab activity during class.
If you are in class and fully engaged with the lab, then you will receive full points for the lab assignment. You do not need to submit your work.
If you have an excused absence, then you will need to complete any class activities you missed within one week of your absence to receive credit. You can submit the completed activity to me via email or slack DM.


Homework (20%)
Homework assignments will be assigned almost every week and due on Fridays at 11:59 PM. The homework will consist of a mix of hand-written exercises, coding exercises, and essays. The purpose of the homework is so that you can demonstrate and grow your conceptual understanding of data science. Homework will be submitted as pdfs on Gradescope and will be graded for correctness, neatness, and clarity.
Late Work Policy. You may turn in two of your homework assignments on the following Tuesday (instead of Friday). Please message me before the original due date if you plan to do this. If you find yourself struggling to meet deadlines outside these two times, then please reach out to me or your class dean so we can help.


Quizzes (30%)
There will be five 30 minute quizzes throughout the semester. All quizzes will be taken during the last 30 minutes of class on TODO. These quizzes will be closed book and closed notes, though you will be allowed to bring one sheet of notes (front and back of an 8x11 piece of paper). If you cannot make a quiz, then please let me know ASAP so we can make alternate arrangements.


Extra Credit Opportunity
Throughout the course, you can earn up to a maximum of 6 extra credit points. These points can be added to your lowest quiz score. You can earn points through any of the following engagement activities:

\(\frac{1}{2}\) point for every question asked on the #questions Slack channel.
\(\frac{1}{2}\) point for every question answered on the #questions Slack channel.
1 point for every math, statistics, or data science talk you attend.
2 points for participating in DataFest (April 17-19).
1 points for completing the course evaluation.

You will keep track of your own extra credit points and let me know how many you earned at the end of the semester.


Project (30%)
The class has a capstone final project where you will work with a partner to conduct and present an original data analysis on a dataset of your choice.
The aim of the project is for you to engage with a data science technique of your choice deeply. You can pick a technique we discussed in this class or choose one you want to learn about. There are many ways you can meaningfully engage with the technique. This may include applying the technique to a dataset, conduct a simulation study where you are comparing multiple methods, implement a new method from a paper, study an intricate proof, create a piece of artwork, etc. Be creative! Whatever you decide should be be challenging and expand your current skill set. (i.e., you can’t do a project you have already done or are currently working on.)
The project consists of the following components (in parentheses is weight of that component’s grade in the overall project grade):

Proposal Presentation (10%)
Exploratory Data Analysis or Preliminary Results (10%)
Peer Review of Preliminary Analysis (10%)
Presentation (30%)
Website for Project (30%)
GitHub Repository (10%)

More information will be provided about the project and the individual components later in the semester.


Final Assignment (5%)
During finals week, you will work on a final assignment consisting of reflective questions.

title: Syllabus
text:
Grade Breakdown
Final grades will be weighted as follows:



Participation
15%


Homework
20%


Quizzes
30%


Project
30%


Final Assignment
5%



I will use the following grading scale:

A: 100-93; A-: < 93-90
B+: < 90-87; B: < 87-83; B-: < 83-80
C+ < 80-77; C: < 77-73; C-: < 73-70
D+: < 70-67; D: < 67-60
F: < 60

Due to the extra credit opportunity, I will not do any rounding.

title: Syllabus
text:
Class Norms
I expect that we all hold ourselves to the following five standards:

Treat others with the dignity and respect.
Embrace productive struggle and making mistakes, and have grace for the mistakes of others.
Ask questions to deepen your understanding, and ask for help when you need it.
Participate to the best of your ability.
Prioritize your health and well-being.

title: Syllabus
text:
Collaboration
Data science is a team sport! I strongly encourage you to form study groups to help complete your homework assignments and prepare for exams. However, I also ask that you take ownership over your work in this course. Everything that you submit on your assignments should be stated in your own words. At the end of each assignment, I will explicitly ask you to list the resources you used (outside of me and the textbook/notes).
Warning. I am more interested in what you are thinking and your (possibly imperfect) work, than in someone else’s (possibly perfect) work. Any submitted work that appears remotely copied from another source or duplicated in another student’s work, especially without citation, will receive no credit. Review the College’s Academic Integrity Guide: https://offices.vassar.edu/dean-of-the-college/documents/https://offices.vassar.edu/dean-of-the-college/documents/

title: Syllabus
text:
Q-Center Peer Support Services
This course fulfills the quantitative analysis (QA) requirement for graduation. All Vassar students have access to free, drop-in, peer-to-peer quantitative tutoring at the Quantitative Reasoning Center (Q-Center). Quantitative tutors (Q-Tutors) excel in a variety of STEM courses. They are typically available Sunday-Thursday 3pm-11pm while classes are in session. Q-Tutors who specialize in Mathematics and Physics are located in the Main Library, Room 122 behind the Writing Center. Q-Tutors who specialize in Chemistry and Economics are located in the Main Library, Room 88 near Special Collections. If you have a quantitative question beyond these four disciplines, Q-Tutors are available to attempt to help you with this question or will help direct you to someone else who may be better able to help. Schedules and other important information can be found at https://offices.vassar.edu/ltrc/qrc/.

title: Syllabus
text:
Academic Accomodations
Academic accommodations are available for students registered with the Office for Accessibility and Educational Opportunity (AEO). Students in need of disability (ADA/504) accommodations should schedule an appointment with me early in the semester to discuss any accommodations for this course that have been approved by the Office for Accessibility and Educational Opportunity, as indicated in your AEO accommodation letter.

title: Syllabus
text:
Title IX Resources
Vassar College is committed to providing a safe learning environment for all students that is free of all forms of discrimination and sexual harassment, including sexual assault, domestic violence, dating violence, and stalking. If you (or someone you know) has experienced or experiences any of these incidents, know that you are not alone. Vassar College has staff members trained to support you in navigating campus life, accessing health and counseling services, providing academic and housing accommodations, helping with legal protective orders, and more.
Please be aware all Vassar faculty members are “responsible employees,” which means that if you tell me about a situation involving sexual harassment, sexual assault, dating violence, domestic violence, or stalking, I must share that information with the Title IX Coordinator. Although I have to make that notification, you will control how your case will be handled, including whether or not you wish to pursue a formal complaint. Our goal is to make sure you are aware of the range of options available to you and have access to the resources you need.
If you wish to speak to someone privately, you can contact any of the following on-campus resources:

Counseling Service (counselingservice.vassar.edu, 845-437-5700)
Health Service (healthservice.vassar.edu, 845-437-5800)
Rachel Gellert, SAVP (Support, Advocacy, and Violence Prevention) director, 845-437-7863)
SAVP advocate, available 24/7 by calling the CRC at 845-437-7333

The SAVP website (savp.vassar.edu and the Title IX section of the EOAA website (eoaa.vassar.edu/title-ix/) have more information, as well as links to both on- and off-campus resources.

Acknowledgement:
The content and structure of this syllabus is modeled after related syllabi from Drs. Simon Hoellerbauer (Trinity College) and Ming-Wen An (Vassar College).

title: Syllabus
text:
Footnotes


Hadley Wickham is a statistician, the creator of the ggplot2 package and the tidyverse, and Chief Scientist at RStudio. He’s from New Zealand, hence the .nz in the links here and above.↩︎
